Context: 1. Some states have recently initiated programs to randomly test high school athletes for possible use of anabolic steroids after concerns arose about the health of the athletes and fairness in the sports. Critics of the programs say that the amount of money spent on testing isn't worth it, since only 1 in 2000 high school athletes actually use steroids to enhance their performance.  The test used does have a 97.3% probability of being positive when an athlete uses steroids and a 98.4% probability of showing a negative result when an athlete is not using steroids.
Q1: a. What is the probability that the test is negative when an athlete is using steroids?
Q2: b. An athlete tests positive.  What is the probability that he really is using steroids?

Context: 2. One out of every 410 American adults is a lawyer - though you find a higher proportion of one out of 64 if you look at just the adults living in the nation's capital of Washington D.C.  Also, the city of Washington D.C.  is where  about 1 out of every 500 Americans live.
Q1: a. What is the probability that a randomly chosen adult American is a lawyer from Washington D.C.?
Q2: b. An American lawyer is picked at random.  What is the probability he or she is from Washington D.C.?

Context: 3. Forty percent of people playing the Minecraft video game in the last 30 days are between the ages of 15 and 21. Only 10% of the whole U.S. population is in that age group, which is the same as the percentage of 15-21 year-olds who have played Minecraft recently.
Q1: a. What is the probability that a randomly selected American has played Minecraft in the last 30 days?
Q2: b. What is the probability that a randomly selected person outside of the age range 15-21 has played Minecraft in the past 30 days?

Context: 4. Two people play a game where one person tosses a coin (probability 0.5 of landing "heads") and the other person tosses a thumbtack (probability 0.32 of landing "point up").  They take turns until a winner is declared when either the person tossing the coin gets a heads or the person tossing the thumbtack gets a point up.  Since the thumbtack has a lower probability on each turn, he gets to go first.
Q1: a. What is the probability that the person playing the thumbtack wins?
Q2: b. Given the thumbtack does not land point up on the first throw, what is the probability of the person with the thumbtack winning?
labelDefs: Note: Node A1 is recursive to node A.
